analysis.weekly_summary: Hey friend, how are you feeling as we head into 2026? This week in the carnivore space has been all about fresh starts and honest conversations. I'm seeing a beautiful mix of practical blueprint content (Anthony Chaffee and Steak and Butter Gal both dropped comprehensive "if I started today" guides) alongside some really vulnerable discussions about the messy middle of this journey. What struck me most? The community is maturing. People aren't just talking about weight loss anymore. They're tracking electrolyte balance, discussing the nuances of different meat sources, and most importantly, being honest about the non-linear nature of healing. Courtney Luna's candid Q&A about her own journey off strict carnivore really resonated with viewers, while Ken Berry sparked important discussions about nutrient diversity (spoiler: you can't actually thrive on beef alone long-term). The vitamin B1 conversation was particularly fascinating from a bio-optimization standpoint. If you're tracking your health markers like I do with my continuous glucose monitor, this week's content offered some solid data points to consider. The undertone? This isn't about perfection. It's about finding your sustainable path to healing. -Sarah

trending_topics.description: Multiple creators released comprehensive "starting carnivore in 2026" guides, capitalizing on New Year motivation with detailed roadmaps. The emphasis shifted from just "eat meat" to nuanced advice about fat ratios, electrolytes, and managing adaptation periods.

Ken Berry sparked discussion by revealing pork as the top B1 source and challenging the "beef only" approach. This opened conversations about the importance of variety in animal foods and why strict limitations might create deficiencies.

trending_topics.topic: The Honesty Wave: Imperfect Carnivore Journeys
trending_topics.description: Creators are getting vulnerable about falling off track, reintroducing foods, and the reality that healing isn't linear. This authenticity is resonating deeply with viewers tired of all-or-nothing messaging.

trending_topics.topic: Common Carnivore Mistakes & Why People Quit
trending_topics.description: Educational content focused on the top reasons people fail (not enough fat, too much dairy, electrolyte mismanagement). Max German and Anthony Chaffee both tackled this with actionable fixes.

Anthony Chaffee's explanation of why people feel worse before better (oxalate crystal release from years of plant consumption) helped many viewers understand their symptoms weren't carnivore failing them.

top_videos.title: If I Started Carnivore in 2026, This is What I'd Do [FULL BLUEPRINT]
top_videos.creator: Anthony Chaffee MD
top_videos.why_notable: Comprehensive blueprint with nearly 1,000 engaged comments. Viewers praised the "eat the damn fat" directness and practical adaptation strategies. The 4-month carnivore in comments sharing their "personal trick" received massive engagement, showing this video is creating real community problem-solving.
top_videos.summary: Dr. Anthony Chaffee shares his complete blueprint for starting the carnivore diet in 2026, covering what to eat, how to handle the transition period, and common mistakes that derail beginners. A key insight is his emphasis on eating fatty cuts of meat to satiety rather than tracking macros or calories, which he says prevents the fatigue and cravings that make people quit early. Watch if you're considering starting carnivore or if you've tried before but struggled with low energy or sustainable results.

comment_sentiment.summary: Enthusiastic supporters of the carnivore diet share personal experiences and gratitude, with minor acknowledgment of past challenges.

top_videos.title: The Best Source Of Vitamin B1 On The Planet
top_videos.creator: KenDBerryMD
top_videos.why_notable: Challenged the "beef only" narrative with data-driven nutrition info. Comments show this filled a real knowledge gap, with viewers expressing relief that their pork consumption is actually beneficial. Important for bio-hackers tracking micronutrient profiles.
top_videos.summary: Dr. Ken Berry reveals that pork is the richest natural source of vitamin B1 (thiamine), containing significantly more than beef or other meats, which matters because many carnivores unknowingly develop B1 deficiency that causes fatigue and brain fog. He explains that eating pork 2-3 times per week can prevent thiamine deficiency without needing supplements, making this especially important for carnivores who primarily eat beef and wonder why they feel tired despite eating enough protein and fat. Watch if you're experiencing unexplained fatigue, poor focus, or muscle weakness on carnivore, as low B1 could be the missing piece.

key_insights: **The Nutrient Diversity Conversation Is Heating Up**: Ken Berry's B1 content challenges the "beef only" dogma. If you're tracking micronutrients (which I recommend via regular blood panels), this matters. Pork, eggs, and organ meats aren't just "allowed" - they're nutritionally strategic. Bio-hackers take note.

**Oxalate Dumping Explains the Adaptation Struggle**: Anthony Chaffee's explanation of why former plant-eaters feel worse initially (crystal deposits releasing from tissues) is helping people stay the course instead of quitting at day 14. This is huge for retention and long-term success.

**Permission for Imperfection Is Resonating**: Courtney Luna's honest discussion about being "mostly carnivore" got more meaningful engagement than many stricter approaches. The community is craving sustainable over perfect. This is the maturation of the movement.

**Electrolyte Management Remains Misunderstood**: Despite years of content, people are still struggling with this. Max German's video highlighting it as a top mistake confirms this is an ongoing education gap. If you're using Whoop or Oura, track how your HRV responds to better sodium/potassium balance.

**The "Why People Quit" Content Performs Exceptionally Well**: Videos addressing failure points and mistakes get high engagement because they validate struggles instead of just celebrating wins. This signals the audience wants problem-solving, not just inspiration.

qa_section.question: How do I know if I'm getting enough fat vs. too much protein?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! When it comes to balancing fat and protein on a carnivore diet, it's all about understanding your body's unique metabolic signals. Research suggests that the ideal macronutrient ratio can vary based on individual factors like activity level, metabolic health, and personal goals.

Using continuous glucose monitors and tracking ketone levels can help you dial in your specific needs. A good starting point is aiming for approximately 70-80% of calories from fat, with protein around 20-30%. Symptoms like persistent hunger, energy crashes, or difficulty maintaining ketosis might indicate you're not hitting the right fat-to-protein balance.

Recent metabolic research indicates that protein intake beyond 1.6-2.2 grams per kg of body weight can potentially trigger gluconeogenesis, which might bump you out of the metabolic state you're seeking. My recommendation? Start tracking your biomarkers. Tools like Levels CGM or Oura Ring can give you real-time insights into how different macronutrient ratios impact your metabolism.

qa_section.question: Why do I feel worse after starting carnivore (oxalate dumping)?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there. First, I want to validate what you're experiencing. The initial phases of dietary shifts, especially something as significant as carnivore, can feel overwhelming. 'Oxalate dumping' is a complex biochemical process that some people report during major dietary transitions.

    Research suggests that when you dramatically reduce plant-based foods and increase animal proteins, your body undergoes significant metabolic adaptation. Some individuals experience temporary symptoms like fatigue, skin changes, or mild inflammation as your cellular detoxification pathways recalibrate. This isn't necessarily harmful, but it's your body's way of processing a radical nutritional shift.

    From a bio-hacking perspective, I recommend tracking your biomarkers closely. If you're using a continuous glucose monitor or Oura ring, monitor how these symptoms correlate with your metabolic responses. Blood tests tracking inflammatory markers like hs-CRP could provide valuable insights into what's happening internally.

qa_section.question: Is it okay to include pork and other meats beyond beef?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there, health explorer! When we're talking about expanding your carnivore diet beyond beef, the research gets really fascinating. Pork and other meats can absolutely be part of a nutrient-dense protein strategy, but it's critical to understand their unique nutritional profiles.

Pork, for instance, offers a different micronutrient profile compared to beef. It's rich in thiamine, selenium, and zinc, which can complement your current nutritional intake. Research from the Journal of Animal Science suggests that meat diversity can actually enhance overall nutrient absorption. My Oura ring data has consistently shown that varied protein sources seem to support more stable energy markers.

That said, quality matters immensely. I always recommend choosing pasture-raised, minimally processed meats. Grass-fed beef and heritage breed pork tend to have better omega-3 to omega-6 ratios, which can support your inflammatory response and metabolic flexibility.

qa_section.question: How do I manage electrolytes properly without feeling awful?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! I totally get how tricky electrolyte management can be, especially when you're exploring a high-protein diet approach. Research suggests that when dramatically shifting nutritional intake, your body's sodium, potassium, and magnesium balance gets disrupted.

Most people on carnivore or ketogenic diets experience 'keto flu' symptoms primarily due to electrolyte imbalances. Your body essentially dumps water and minerals during metabolic adaptation. I recommend targeted supplementation: aim for 3-5g sodium, 1-2g potassium, and 300-500mg magnesium daily. My Oura Ring tracking actually helped me notice precise mineral depletion patterns during my own metabolic transitions.

The key is gradual adaptation. Don't just dump salt randomly - track your body's response. Consider using electrolyte powders without artificial sweeteners, and monitor how you feel. Blood glucose tracking (I'm a huge fan of continuous glucose monitors) can provide real-time insights into your metabolic response.

qa_section.question: Can I still be successful if I'm not 100% strict carnivore?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! I totally get where you're coming from with this carnivore diet curiosity. The good news is that dietary approaches aren't about perfection - they're about finding what works for YOUR unique body and healing journey.

Research suggests that flexibility can actually be a strength in nutritional strategies. A 2020 study in Nutrients showed that even 'modified' carnivore approaches can deliver metabolic benefits. What matters most is nutrient density and how your body responds. I've seen clients get incredible results by being around 80% consistent, rather than trying to be 100% rigid.

My recommendation? Use blood glucose tracking (I'm a big fan of continuous monitors like Levels or Abbott's FreeStyle Libre) to understand how different protein and fat ratios impact YOUR individual metabolism. Everyone's biochemistry is different, so personalized data trumps one-size-fits-all dogma.

qa_section.question: What about vitamin B1 and other nutrients on beef-only?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! When we're talking about a beef-only diet and vitamin B1 (thiamine), there are some critical nutritional considerations to unpack. Research suggests that while beef contains some thiamine, a carnivore diet might put you at risk for potential deficiencies.

Beef isn't the most robust source of vitamin B1, and a strict carnivore approach could lead to marginal intake. Most beef provides around 0.04-0.06 mg of thiamine per 100g, which is significantly lower than recommended daily intake (1.1-1.2 mg for adults). My tracker data from continuous glucose monitoring and blood panels shows nutrient diversity is key - and beef alone might not hit those optimization markers.

What's fascinating is how individual metabolic responses can vary. While some bio-hackers report feeling incredible on carnivore protocols, the long-term nutritional profile requires careful monitoring. I'd recommend regular blood work, potentially supplementing with a high-quality B-complex, and tracking biomarkers through platforms like Levels or InsideTracker to understand your personal metabolic response.

qa_section.question: How long does the adaptation period really take?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! When it comes to the carnivore diet adaptation period, most people report significant metabolic shifts between 4-12 weeks. My Oura ring and continuous glucose monitoring have helped me track some fascinating metabolic transitions during similar nutritional protocols.

    Research suggests the initial adaptation isn't just about diet - it's a complex metabolic recalibration. Your body transitions from glucose metabolism to primarily fat and protein oxidation, which can trigger significant physiological changes. Folks often experience temporary symptoms like fatigue, electrolyte fluctuations, and metabolic recalibration during this window. I always recommend working with a healthcare professional and tracking key biomarkers like inflammation markers, lipid panels, and glucose response.

    The critical piece is understanding individual variation. While some people report feeling remarkable within 4-6 weeks, others might take 10-12 weeks to fully adapt. Your unique metabolic profile, existing health status, and genetic factors play massive roles in how quickly your body transitions.

qa_section.question: Is dairy preventing my progress?
qa_section.answer:
Hey there! When it comes to dairy and its potential impact on your health journey, the research is nuanced. Recent studies suggest that dairy's effects can vary dramatically based on individual metabolic responses and gut microbiome composition.

    A fascinating area of emerging research looks at how dairy proteins, particularly casein and whey, interact with individual inflammatory markers. Some people experience increased insulin response and inflammatory signals, while others metabolize dairy quite efficiently. My recommendation is always to track your personal biomarkers. Tools like continuous glucose monitors (I'm a big fan of the latest Levels CGM technology) can give real-time insight into how different dairy products impact your unique metabolic profile.

    For those following stricter protocols like carnivore or ketogenic diets, full-fat dairy from grass-fed sources often shows more promising metabolic outcomes. Specifically, fermented options like kefir or aged cheeses tend to have lower lactose and potentially more beneficial probiotic profiles.

top_comments.text:
For boiling:
‚Ä¢ 2 cups dry green or brown lentils
‚Ä¢ 1 large potato peeled
‚Ä¢ 1 onion peeled
2 whole carrots peeled
water to cover
‚Ä¢ Salt to taste
For the mixture:
‚Ä¢ 1 cup breadcrumbs (Add more if needed)
‚Ä¢ 1 cup chopped fresh parsley
1-2 tsp paprika
‚Ä¢ 1 tsp ground cumin
Salt and pepper to taste
Optional: chili flakes

For frying:
‚Ä¢ Oil for shallow frying
For serving:
Turkish-style bread rolls or Pita
Yogurt-based sauce like Tzatziki
‚Ä¢ Tomato slices
‚Ä¢ Onion slices mixed with parsley and sumac
‚Ä¢ Grilled long green peppers (optional)
Pickles (optional)

Instructions
Cook the lentils and vegetables:
Add the lentils to a large pot. Place the whole potato, onion, and carrots on top.
Cover with water, season lightly with salt, and cook until everything is soft (about 25-30 minutes).

2
Mash everything:
Drain excess water if there is any. Mash the lentils, carrots, onion, and potato together in the pot until mostly smooth but still a little chunky.
3
Make the mixture:
Transfer the mash to a bowl. Add breadcrumbs, chopped parsley, paprika, cumin, salt, pepper, and chili flakes (optional). Mix until the mixture holds together. Add more breadcrumbs if needed.

4
Shape patties:
Form oval or square patties by pressing the mixture firmly with your hands.
5
Fry:
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat. Fry patties on both sides until golden brown and crispy.

Assemble sandwiches:
Slice the bread, add the sauce, tomato slices, onion-parsley mix, 3-4 lentil patties, and grilled green pepper. Press lightly and enjoy warm!

top_comments.text:
Meat is digested in the stomach with strong acid, while plants are fermented in the gut.

If you only eat plants, you don‚Äôt need high stomach acid, so your body stops making it. This becomes a problem if you start eating meat again because you won‚Äôt have enough acid to digest it. The fix is to gradually increase meat consumption so your stomach acid production ramps up again.

You also need bile to digest animal fats. If you‚Äôre not eating fat, your bile flow slows, bile thickens into sludge and gallstones can form. When you suddenly reintroduce fat, you may not digest it well because your bile ducts can be blocked. To get bile flowing again, bile salts and gradually increasing animal fat can help.

Bile is released from the gallbladder when you eat fat and it‚Äôs not just for fat digestion. Bile salts also act as a natural intestinal lubricant and mild laxative, keeping stool soft and triggering the muscular contractions that move waste along. Low bile output makes stool drier, harder and slower to pass.

If you‚Äôre sensitive to histamine, source non-hung/aged meat straight from a slaughterhouse.

A plant-based, low-animal-fat diet is not good for long-term health, despite what‚Äôs promoted. Humans are designed to eat meat and animal fats.  Things start breaking down when we don‚Äôt.

took 9 mo's for me to adapt. Why did I keep on going? Cause I knew I introduced change. However along the way the changes were nothing short of miraculous 4 days into it. In fact even the next morning I seen changes. I'm now 2 years 6 mo's carni. I do the best on the lion diet but, do make a bone broth out of a whole chicken and am now also introducing a pro-biotic for gut thru home made yogurt. I feel the need to get more gut intestinal tract better. I had a mild form of  hyperglycemia to which now is gone. I also make my own butter. For some reason store bought butter does not settle well with me.. The last milestone will be to illuminate coffee. I've noted post nasal drip comes when I drink it and not when I don't. 
So yeah am I pro Carni... absolutely. Why ? Cause I got my life back and never had even a sniffle of sickness ever since. I don't sunburn, I don't sweat like a fermenting pig, I don't have brain fog, I don't have a bad attitude anymore. I sleep very well, I have tons of energy and I take the time every day to meditate and give thoughts where I'm going.

top_comments.text: As a 4-month carnivore I feel the need to tell you my personal trick. The thing I hated the most is the mess on my stove from cooking in a pan. About two months ago I switched to the air fryer. I put the steak in the air fryer, put some bacon drippings over the top of each steak (luckily my local butcher makes his own bacon and sells the bacon drippings), salt on top and then cook it to my liking. It goes on the plate and then I pour the dripping from the air fryer over the top on my meat like a sauce and it is delicious. Easy clean up and no messy stove. Just enjoying sharing what works for me. Cheers from Australia.
top_comments.author: @eltsac9319

6 years carnivore December 12th 2025. What i wish i knew when i started was how important salt is on a low carb/zero carb/carnivore lifestyle. And i started because i felt like my lifelong epilepsy was killing me slowly. Nothing was working, and after seeing a dr and her telling me i needed antidepressants, i realised i wasn't going to get any help from my dr and i'd have to figure my health out for myself. After some research i came upon carnivore and it changed my life. I came from a standard western diet (uk) from childhood to teen, then to a bodybuilders diet through my mid 20s to thirties - which i would call plant based and low fat - and is where i felt my absolute worst, and then carnivore from age 40. I'm 46 now. And like i said earlier. Carnivore changed my life!!
But i didn't know that salt would be so important and possibly the reason why i developed epilepsy in the first place. My mum told me she never used salt in her cooking - and still doesn't (and she's always suffering somethingü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è) i had absences when i was a child and full blown seizures after i started my periods. When i think back to my past, i don't remember much because i was always sick. I never felt well within myself. And so when i dig deeper into this carnivore diet, different branches of information lead back to how i felt as a youngster and lightbulbs are going off!! Could a lack of salt have caused this? Why do i have seizures on my period mostly, and why does salt always make me feel better straight away? I never added it all together until nearly 6 years in because i thought stopping the seizures was all about the fat - and it wasn't! At least for me! High fat carnivore drastically reduced the seizures to almost nothing but adding/supplementing salt - was the cherry on top! The bow that tied it all together! This has blown my mind! And salt isn't just important for me and my epilepsy, its important for human health overall and i believe everybody should be using it daily. Dr Chaffee... i tell ya, if i knew this when i started... life changing. Meat, fat and plenty of salt guys. This is all we need.

top_comments.text:
Thanks Dr. Chaffee for the reminder about ammonia from protein breakdown.
When I first went keto (full carnivore now), I had a strong ammonia smell on my body for a few months. Really concerning at the time and I couldn't find any information about it. Eventually it just disappeared.
After hearing you mention this, I searched again and it's well-documented now. It's caused by excess protein breakdown during adaptation. Your body produces ammonia as a byproduct, and during transition it gets released through sweat and breath.
Good news: it's temporary and normal. Typically resolves within weeks to months once you're fat-adapted.
If anyone else is experiencing this, don't panic. Stay hydrated, keep electrolytes balanced (especially potassium), and eat enough fat relative to protein. Your body is just adapting.
Hope this helps someone going through it right now.

That I was being kind to animals‚Ä¶now I‚Äôm being kind to myself and being more grateful for my food, and I know meat is necessary. I don‚Äôt need anything else. Fatty meat, eggs, a bit of dairy here and there, salt, water. Thank you Dr Chaffee. I eat way more calories than I used 2000-3000 a day. I just listen to my body and eat when I feel hunger and I am very lean. I‚Äôm usually hungry once a day in the afternoon. Sometimes again in the evening if I had a workout earlier or if my cycle is coming on and I crave more fat. My skin is glowing. I had so much clogged pores before always squeezing out sebum. I‚Äôm not craving food at all multiple times a day because of insulin spikes or drops. Just real hunger where food tastes savory again and not binging from messed up signals. Everytime I have tried to eat plants again my gut hurts and I get gas, feel nauseous and my skin starts having issues. Funny how many people think I‚Äôm crazy and won‚Äôt eat plants. I‚Äôm the canary in the coal mine. My gut will scream if there is anything it does not like and knows is toxic. People say oh you just need to get back to a place of healing. When your gut heals enough eat plants again. Why would I eat what caused the issues in the first place. You‚Äôre all missing the point of plant toxins. üçì‚ö†Ô∏è Are raspberries actually as healthy as we think?
In this clip, Dave Asprey breaks down why some fruits ‚Äî especially certain berries ‚Äî may cause issues for some people due to oxalates, compounds that can bind to calcium and form sharp microscopic crystals in the body.

This conversation explores how oxalate-rich foods may impact urinary health, inflammation, and sensitivity in some individuals, and why berries like blueberries are often considered a gentler option. Not all fruit affects the body the same way ‚Äî and understanding these differences can help you make smarter, more personalized nutrition choices.

top_comments.text:
Beef (especially certain cuts)
Yes, beef absolutely contains thiamine‚Äîjust not as concentrated as pork.
Ground beef (especially 70/30 or 75/25)
‚Ä¢ ~0.05‚Äì0.07 mg B1 per 100 g
‚Ä¢ Adds up quickly if beef is your staple
Chuck, round, brisket
‚Ä¢ Similar thiamine content
Eating 1.5‚Äì2 lb of beef/day provides a meaningful baseline intake
 Beef alone can cover a substantial portion of B1 needs, especially in low-carb metabolism where thiamine demand is lower.
2. Ruminant Organs (this is where people forget)
If ancient Yisrael did anything right nutritionally, it was nose-to-tail.
Liver (beef or lamb)
‚Ä¢ ~0.1‚Äì0.2 mg B1 per 100 g
‚Ä¢ Also supplies magnesium and other B vitamins that work with thiamine
Heart
‚Ä¢ Comparable or slightly higher B1 than liver
Kidney
‚Ä¢ Often overlooked, but legit source
üëâ Even 1‚Äì2 small servings per week materially improves thiamine status.
3. Fish with Scales and Fins (Leviticus 11‚Äìclean)
This is a big one people ignore.
Tuna
Salmon
Mackerel
Sardines
Thiamine content varies, but:
~0.05‚Äì0.1 mg B1 per 100 g
Sardines punch above their weight nutritionally
‚ö†Ô∏è One note of precision: raw fish contains thiaminase, which destroys B1.
‚û°Ô∏è Cooking deactivates thiaminase, so cooked fish = no problem.
4. Eggs (supportive, not primary)
Eggs won‚Äôt carry the whole load, but they contribute.
~0.03 mg B1 per large egg
Also supply sulfur, choline, and B2, which support energy metabolism
Think of eggs as backup singers, not the lead guitar.
5. Dairy (if tolerated)
Not huge, but not zero.
Raw or full-fat milk
Hard cheeses
Low thiamine density, but:
Adds calories without carb load
Supports overall B-vitamin balance
Why pork looks ‚Äúspecial‚Äù (but isn‚Äôt necessary)
Pork is high in thiamine per gram, yes. That‚Äôs why Berry harps on it.
But here‚Äôs the part people gloss over:
Thiamine deficiency risk skyrockets with high carbohydrate intake
On low-carb / carnivore, B1 requirements drop
Ruminant meat + organs + fish easily cover needs
Ancient Yisrael didn‚Äôt need pigs to function. Neither do you.

 Beef (especially fatty ground)
 Ruminant organs
 Clean fish (cooked)
 Eggs
 Optional dairy
All Leviticus 11‚Äìcompliant. All carnivore-compatible. All sufficient for vitamin B1.

videos.title: Easiest Kebab Recipe Ever
videos.description:
Comment BEEFY if you‚Äôd love to try this!

Follow me for more delicious Ôøºand easy carnivore tips and recipes!

top_comments.text:
Meat Kebab Recipe

Ingredients:
-2 LBs 85/15 ground beef
-1 Large onion, grated
-3 garlic cloves
-1/4 cup whole milk greek yogurt
-2 tsp Cumin
-1 tsp Paprika
-1 tsp Oregano
-1 tsp Salt
-1/2 tsp Black pepper

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 400 F
2. Add all ingredients into a large bowl, mix well.
3. Divide in to 4 equal portions.
4. Place one portion into center of parchment paper (12x16).
5. Place another paper same size on top.
6. Use rolling pin/hands to roll mix into thin rectangle.
7. Starting from long side, fold parchment over meat
8. Roll tightly until forms flat compact log. Repeat.
9. Bake 400 F for 15 mins.
10. Let cool just enough to handle, unroll.
11. Break into slices or small chunks, return to baking sheet.
12. Broil for 2-3 mins (lightly golden / crisp).

videos.title: Fluffy carnivore cake recipe
videos.description:
Comment ‚ÄúCAKE‚Äù for the recipe to this delicious carnivore cake

Comment ‚ÄúCAKE‚Äù if you would love to try this 100% carnivore fluffy cake recipe!

This is truly the perfect base to any cake you could possibly want to make! I‚Äôve made this as a birthday cream cake for my brother‚Äôs birthday, a low carb strawberry shortcake so many times, even turned it into fluffy cookies! 
Every time I make this cake, my family says ‚Äúits the best tasting healthy cake they‚Äôve ever eaten‚Äù üòÜShoutout to Kelly for creating this. @kelly_hogan91 
 
Recipe:
-separate 8 egg yolks from the whites
-in one bowl, mix well the 8 yolks with 8 oz cream cheese 
-in another bowl, beat whites until they become as stiff as possible
-slowly and gently pour and fold the yolk mix into bowl of whites
-bake cake(s) in baking sheet at 300 Fahrenheit for 25 min
-apply whipped heavy whipping cream or any frosting you like all over cake
-you can customize this basic recipe to add whatever ingredients you‚Äôd like!

top_comments.text:
One of the things we did was:
* realize that the four grams of carbohydrates we need daily is made by our liver. 
* realize that anything over that amount has to be either burned immediately or stored in a fat cell. 
* realize that 4 grams of carbohydrates equals an entire teaspoon of sugar. 
...Then we read labels and, in horror, simply threw out things in our pantry that we would never eat again. 
We immediately donated our toaster and our rice maker. That's the commitment you have got to do. Label reading and deciding. It's not easy, but it's the right thing and the right thing isn't always easy, but it's always right.

videos.title: An Honest Conversation
videos.description:
This felt like a good time to slow down and have an honest conversation.

I pulled questions from the community and answered them openly, covering carnivore, health, mindset, and some life changes I‚Äôve been navigating. Nothing rehearsed, nothing polished, just where I‚Äôm at right now.

I‚Äôd really love to hear from you after watching. What resonated? What surprised you? Or what questions do you still have?

If you‚Äôre new here, welcome,  I‚Äôm glad you found your way to this conversation.

00:00 An honest check-in
00:49 Why I wanted to do this Q&A
01:07 Let‚Äôs talk about my hair (and keeping things simple)
02:55 Healing acne & the role of diet
04:29 Thoughts on keto desserts & food triggers
05:50 The biggest change carnivore brought to my life
06:47 Snacks, fasting, and eating enough
08:03 Feeling stuck with weight loss
08:52 Sardines, nutrition & old experiments
09:25 Will I stay carnivore forever?
11:53 Heartburn, nausea & adjusting to carnivore
12:28 Holiday meals & favorite foods
14:19 Dairy vs meat ‚Äî is there a ‚Äúwrong‚Äù way?
15:08 Will I write another cookbook?
18:12 Consistency, cravings & food noise
20:13 Seasonings, salt & flavor
21:02 Meeting people from the community
21:46 Van life nerves & safety fears
22:21 Big life changes & moving into van life
23:23 Travel plans, the Carolinas & what‚Äôs next
24:26 Camper life realities (yes, including the toilet)
25:52 A possible podcast with Jeff
27:04 Protecting family & sharing life online

videos.title: Carnivore pancake recipe! #carnivorediet #carnivorerecipes #ketodiet #ketorecipes #ketopancakes

top_comments.text:
CARNIVORE PANCAKE RECIPE:

3 eggs separated
2.5 tbsp collagen (I use @equipfoods brand vanilla, you can also use unflavored if you're strict, the flavored has stevia. Code Luna to save 20% off)
1 tbsp beef gelatin (brand NuNaturals unflavored off Amazon)

Whip egg whites until stiff peaks form, about 3 minutes and add gelatin while blending.
Blend the yolks with the collagen.
Fold white mixture into yolk mixture.
Pan fry for about 5 minutes on each side using medium-low heat, cover with lid or parchment paper. Enjoy!

Recipe from Maria Emmerich ‚ù§

top_comments.text:
Main reasons imo why they fail is‚Ä¶ (btw saying this as 1 year strict carnivore, 1.5 normal carnivore (including dairy) and 3 years raw primal/raw carnivore prior to starting carnivore so not inexperienced in carnivore lifestyle) 

- Convenience (financial convenience, sourcing convenience eg. Fats, bone marrow, organs, grass fed/grass finished, social convenience, regional convenience eg. Going on holiday to a resort where meals are prepaid for and you can‚Äôt be completely carnivore. 

- Adaptation struggles in early phases. Stool movement problems, (Possibly Bile Acid Malabsorption, or most commonly not eating enough fat causing constipation.) heart palpitation from an energy prioritisation change (hearing beat in ear when sleeping, this passes after some time but the more you cheat and mess with carbs, the longer the process), possible tiredness from not utilising fat for energy as well in initial phases which gets better but don‚Äôt stop training (whether on carb or fat diet, people who train will know that when you stop, your endurance ends up dropping and so does strength. Understanding exercise timing is important. The meals in carnivore diets a larger and longer to digest meals usually so exercise feels best imo either in the morning before eating large meals or 5-6 hours after a large meal. It‚Äôs not that you won‚Äôt have energy but your body will be taxed more when trying to process a large meal and also being put through physically straining exercise at the same time . Little pro tip though, if you insist on eating before workout, eggs digest really fast compared to other carnivore foods. 27 mins for eggs to digest. I personally don‚Äôt really do little snack meals on carnivore usually but if you feel really hungry and sluggish to workout perhaps due to not fully adapting or maybe due to the last meal before being too long ago, eggs are amazing because they digest faster and satiating. 
Mineral/vitamin imbalances perhaps but I never had this for any other than vitamin D for which I was just told to take tablets for a bit then make sure once I get through the tablets to get enough sunlight. as someone who has bloodworks done like once a year, I didn‚Äôt have any other deficiencies in vitamins/minerals. 

- Locking yourself in mid dke of animal base/carnivore and constantly going in and out of keto so not feeling as good. 

-Overloading on caffeine. Yes you‚Äôre not having sugar and it‚Äôs still keto but it‚Äôs still not ideal and using coffee as a way of weight loss and ensuring stool movement is not the ideal way to do carnivore. In my opinion, it‚Äôs not even carnivore but it‚Äôs still animal based ketovore so still really good but if you overdo it, then you end up taking over certain stuff that switching to carnivore/keto should do anyway. And coffee still has oxalates so on a diet trying to lower antinutrients, drinking coffee isn‚Äôt ideal and I understand some people love their morning coffee but they‚Äôre not giving themselves the chance to experience how great it feels to be in ketosis and not need coffee to wake them up. And also, drinking coffee makes you not get hungry but you already shouldn‚Äôt be getting hungry anyway if you eat until you‚Äôre full on carnivore on fat and meat meals. You may not eat enough due to this and then yes you will lose weight but you‚Äôll lose it in a nutritionally deficient way, so not in a healthy manner. If you wanna lose weight and your eating as much as you want before full is too much for weight loss goals, then you can do so with different ratios of fat/protein. Increasing the fat ratio works for some because it‚Äôs calorically higher yes but practically it‚Äôs also more satiating and usually people can‚Äôt eat as much after. Plus adjusting training to match weight loss goals can help since weight isn‚Äôt just dietary. You can also implement raw meat/fat. I‚Äôve found that eating raw meat of same volume can keep me satiated for longer than cooked meat. However, with raw fat, although I feel more satiated, I can also eat way more raw fat in a sitting than cooked fat so that may change based on the person. 
There‚Äôs also different outcomes based on high meat but a carnivore beginner probably won‚Äôt need to concern themselves with high meat lol. 

I could probably come up with more but Im tired of writing.
top_comments.author: @denizkenger52
